The original and second Death Stars.

**Death Star** is the name of a number of fictional mobile [space
stations](/wiki/Space_station "Space station") and galactic
[superweapons](/wiki/Weapon_of_mass_destruction "Weapon of mass destruction")
featured in the _[Star Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars "Star Wars")_ [space
opera](/wiki/Space_opera "Space opera") franchise. The first Death Star was
stated to be more than 100 km to 160 km in diameter, depending on source. It
was crewed by an estimated 1.7 million military personnel and 400,000
droids.[1][2] Its superweapon delivered enough energies on a scale equivalent
to all the energy released by the Sun in an entire week.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
second Death Star was significantly larger, between 200 km to 400 km in
diameter depending on source, and technologically more advanced than its
predecessor. Both versions of these [dwarf planet](/wiki/Dwarf_planet "Dwarf
planet")-sized fortresses were designed for massive [power
projection](/wiki/Power_projection "Power projection") capabilities, capable
of destroying multiple [naval fleets](/wiki/Naval_fleet "Naval fleet") or
entire planets with one blast from their superlasers.[3]

## Origin and
design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Origin and design")]

Although details, such as the superlaser's location, shifted between different
concept models during production of [_Star Wars_](/wiki/Star_Wars_\(film\)
"Star Wars \(film\)"), the notion of the Death Star being a large, spherical
space station over 100 kilometers in diameter was consistent in all of
them.[4] George Lucas gave the original task of designing a "Death Star" to
concept artist and spaceship modeler Colin Cantwell,[5] who had collaborated
with [Stanley Kubrick](/wiki/Stanley_Kubrick "Stanley Kubrick") on the 1968
film _[2001: A Space Odyssey](/wiki/2001:_A_Space_Odyssey_\(film\) "2001: A
Space Odyssey \(film\)")_.[6] In a 2016 interview, Cantwell related that "I
didn't originally plan for the Death Star to have a trench, but when I was
working with the mold, I noticed the two halves had shrunk at the point where
they met across the middle." As it "would have taken a week of work just to
fill and sand and refill this depression," Cantwell suggested a trench to
Lucas to save the labor. Lucas liked the idea,[5][6] and the Death Star model
was created by [John Stears](/wiki/John_Stears "John Stears").[7][8] The
buzzing sound counting down to the Death Star firing its superlaser comes from
the _[Flash Gordon](/wiki/Flash_Gordon "Flash Gordon")_ serials.[9] Portraying
an incomplete yet powerful space station posed a problem for [Industrial Light
& Magic](/wiki/Industrial_Light_%26_Magic "Industrial Light & Magic")'s
modelmakers for _[Return of the Jedi](/wiki/Return_of_the_Jedi "Return of the
Jedi")_.[10] Only the front side of the 137-centimeter model was completed,
and the image was flipped horizontally for the final film.[10] Both Death
Stars were depicted by a combination of complete and sectional models and
[matte paintings](/wiki/Matte_painting "Matte painting").[4][10]

### Special effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Special effects")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/ee/Starwars_explosion.jpg/200px-
Starwars_explosion.jpg)](/wiki/File:Starwars_explosion.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Starwars_explosion.jpg "Enlarge")

The explosion special effect.

The Death Star explosions featured in the special edition of _A New Hope_ and
in _Return of the Jedi_ are rendered with a [Praxis
effect](/wiki/Praxis_effect "Praxis effect"), wherein a flat ring of matter
erupts from the explosion.

The grid plan animations shown during the Rebel briefing for the attack on the
Death Star late in _A New Hope_ were an actual computer graphics simulation
from the [Jet Propulsion Laboratory](/wiki/Jet_Propulsion_Laboratory "Jet
Propulsion Laboratory") made by [Larry Cuba](/wiki/Larry_Cuba "Larry Cuba")
and [Gary Imhoff](/wiki/Gary_Imhoff "Gary Imhoff") as part of a
[CalArts](/wiki/CalArts "CalArts") project, and had been included during
filming.[11]

section: Depiction")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/ee/Vaderrots.jpeg/220px-
Vaderrots.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Vaderrots.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Vaderrots.jpeg "Enlarge")

[Emperor Palpatine](/wiki/Palpatine "Palpatine") (left) and [Darth
Vader](/wiki/Darth_Vader "Darth Vader") (right) watch the original Death
Star's construction in _[Star Wars: Episode III – Revenge of the
Sith](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_III_%E2%80%93_Revenge_of_the_Sith "Star Wars:
Episode III – Revenge of the Sith")_.

These are depictions of the Death Star and other similar weapons of mass
destruction within the [_Star Wars_ canon](/wiki/Star_Wars_canon "Star Wars
canon").

### _Death Star_
-class[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Death Star-class")]

#### _DS-1_ Platform - (Star Wars: Episode IV – A New
Hope)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: DS-1 Platform - \(Star Wars: Episode IV – A New Hope\)")]

The original Death Star's completed form appears in [_Star
Wars_](/wiki/Star_Wars_\(film\) "Star Wars \(film\)"), known officially as the
**DS-1 Orbital Battle Station** , or **Project Stardust** in _[Rogue
One](/wiki/Rogue_One "Rogue One")_. Commanded by Governor Tarkin, it is the
[Galactic Empire](/wiki/Galactic_Empire_\(Star_Wars\) "Galactic Empire \(Star
Wars\)")'s "ultimate weapon",[12] a huge spherical space station over 100
kilometers in diameter capable of destroying a planet with one shot of its
superlaser. The film opens with [Princess Leia](/wiki/Princess_Leia "Princess
Leia") transporting the station's [schematics](/wiki/Schematics "Schematics")
to the [Rebel Alliance](/wiki/Rebel_Alliance "Rebel Alliance") to aid them in
destroying the Death Star. Tarkin orders the Death Star to destroy Leia's home
world of [Alderaan](/wiki/Alderaan "Alderaan") in an attempt to press her into
giving him the location of the secret Rebel base; she gives them the false
location of [Dantooine](/wiki/Dantooine "Dantooine"), but Tarkin has Alderaan
destroyed anyway, as a demonstration of the Death Star's firepower and the
Empire's resolve. Later, [Luke Skywalker](/wiki/Luke_Skywalker "Luke
Skywalker"), [Han Solo](/wiki/Han_Solo "Han Solo"),
[Chewbacca](/wiki/Chewbacca "Chewbacca"), [Obi-Wan Kenobi](/wiki/Obi-
Wan_Kenobi "Obi-Wan Kenobi"), [C-3PO](/wiki/C-3PO "C-3PO"), and
[R2-D2](/wiki/R2-D2 "R2-D2") are pulled aboard the station by a [tractor
beam](/wiki/Tractor_beam "Tractor beam"), where they discover and manage to
rescue Princess Leia. As they make their escape, Obi-Wan dies fighting Darth
Vader, enabling the others to flee the station. Later, Luke returns as part of
a fighter force to attack its only weak point: a ray-shielded particle exhaust
vent leading straight from the surface directly into its reactor core. Luke
was able to successfully launch his fighter's torpedoes into the vent,
impacting the core and triggering a catastrophic explosion, which completely
destroyed the station before it could use its superlaser weapon to annihilate
its intended target, the rebel base on Yavin IV.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

_[The Clone Wars](/wiki/The_Clone_Wars "The Clone Wars")_ Legacy story reel
from the unfinished _Crystal Crisis on Utapau_ episodes revealed that the
reason [General Grievous](/wiki/General_Grievous "General Grievous") was on
Utapau in _Revenge of the Sith_ was to acquire enormous [kyber
crystals](/wiki/Kyber_crystal "Kyber crystal"), which were required to power
the Death Star's superlaser.[13]

The first Death Star's schematics are visible in the scenes on Geonosis in
_[Star Wars: Episode II – Attack of the
Clones](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_II_%E2%80%93_Attack_of_the_Clones "Star Wars:
Episode II – Attack of the Clones")_ showcasing the early development of the
Death Star prototype, the Death Star plans were designed by
[Geonosians](/wiki/Geonosian "Geonosian") led by Archduke [Poggle the
Lesser](/wiki/Poggle_the_Lesser "Poggle the Lesser"), a member of the
[Confederacy of Independent Systems](/wiki/Confederacy_of_Independent_Systems
"Confederacy of Independent Systems"), and is shown early in construction at
the end of _[Star Wars: Episode III – Revenge of the
Sith](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_III_%E2%80%93_Revenge_of_the_Sith "Star Wars:
Episode III – Revenge of the Sith")_. The Death Star plans are a central plot-
point in the 2016 film _[Rogue One](/wiki/Rogue_One "Rogue One")_ and the
original 1977 film _[Star Wars: Episode IV – A New
Hope](/wiki/Star_Wars_\(film\) "Star Wars \(film\)")_.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

A hologram from the original Death Star is briefly visible in a scene at the
Resistance base in _[Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force
Awakens](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Force_Awakens "Star Wars: The Force Awakens")_
and used as a means of comparison with one from the [First
Order](/wiki/First_Order_\(Star_Wars\) "First Order \(Star Wars\)")'s own
superweapon, Starkiller Base.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In the animated series _[Star Wars Rebels](/wiki/Star_Wars_Rebels "Star Wars
Rebels")_ , the two-part episode "Ghost of Geonosis" hinted that the
Geonosians were nearly wiped out to extinction out of the Empire's need for
secrecy. [Saw Gerrera](/wiki/Saw_Gerrera "Saw Gerrera"), having been sent to
Geonosis to investigate, deduced the Empire possesses a superweapon and
resolved to discover the Death Star as depicted in the final season two-parter
"In the Name of the Rebellion." Though it was a dead end, finding only
scientists being abducted by the Empire, Saw learned the weapon is powered by
kyber crystals taken from the Jedha system.

The [anthology film](/wiki/Star_Wars#Anthology_series "Star Wars") _[Rogue
One](/wiki/Rogue_One "Rogue One")_ focuses on a band of Rebels stealing the
plans for the first Death Star prior to the events of _A New Hope_. The Death
Star project was overseen by Orson Krennic, the Director of Advanced Weapons
Research for the Imperial Military. Under Krennic's supervision, the project
was beset by constant delays, and he forcibly recruited weapons designer Galen
Erso (the father of Jyn Erso, the movie's main protagonist) to complete the
design; nevertheless, it was another fifteen years before the Death Star was
operational. The Death Star's primary laser was powered by kyber crystals
mined from the desert moon of [Jedha](/wiki/Jedha "Jedha"), and is first used
to destroy Jedha City both as a response to a violent insurgency on the
planet, and as a display of the Death Star's operational status to restore the
Empire's confidence in the project. Grand Moff Tarkin assumes control over the
Death Star while Krennic investigates security breaches in the design project.
It is subsequently revealed that Galen discreetly sabotaged the design by
building a vulnerability into the reactor. This is the same vulnerability that
Luke Skywalker takes advantage of during the events of _A New Hope_. After the
Death Star plans are stolen from the Scarif vault, Tarkin fires the Death Star
laser on the base killing Krennic, as well as Jyn Erso and Cassian
Andor.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

The canonical population of the first Death Star was 1.7 million military
personnel, 400,000 maintenance droids, and 250,000 civilians/independent
contractors.[1][2]

The 2014 book _[Star Wars: Tarkin](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Tarkin "Star Wars:
Tarkin")_ detailed the life of [Grand Moff Tarkin](/wiki/Grand_Moff_Tarkin
"Grand Moff Tarkin"), and prominently featured the first Death Star. The theme
of the construction of the Death Star is continued in the 2016 book,
_[Catalyst: A Rogue One Novel](/wiki/Catalyst:_A_Rogue_One_Novel "Catalyst: A
Rogue One Novel")_ , which tells the story of the development of the Death
Star's superweapon by the scientist, [Galen Erso](/wiki/Galen_Erso "Galen
Erso") and Krennic's deception of him. It also reveals how Poggle worked with
Krennic on the Project but then turned on him.[14]

In the film _[Rogue One](/wiki/Rogue_One "Rogue One"),_ it is revealed that
the Death Star's superlaser is powered by multiple reactors, allowing it to
vary its destructive power depending on the target. Skeptical of the station's
power, Tarkin ordered that it first be tested on Jedha City using a single
reactor. Subsequently, a second single-reactor test would destroy their
installation on Scarif, along with the Rebel strike force who had successfully
stolen the station's plans. The destruction of the planet
[Alderaan](/wiki/Alderaan "Alderaan") would be the first time the Death Star
was tested with all reactors employed.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

#### _DS-2_ Platform - (Star Wars: Episode VI – Return of the
Jedi)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: DS-2 Platform - \(Star Wars: Episode VI – Return of the Jedi\)")]

_[Return of the Jedi](/wiki/Return_of_the_Jedi "Return of the Jedi")_ features
a second Death Star still under construction in orbit around the second moon
of [Endor](/wiki/Endor_\(Star_Wars\) "Endor \(Star Wars\)"). [Emperor
Palpatine](/wiki/Palpatine "Palpatine") and [Darth Vader](/wiki/Darth_Vader
"Darth Vader") send the Rebels false information that the station's weapons
systems are not operational in order to lure them into a trap. When the
station's protective shield is disabled by a ground assault team on the forest
moon of the planet Endor (led by Han Solo) with the help of the native
[Ewoks](/wiki/Ewoks "Ewoks"), rebel fighters flew into the unfinished station
targeting its reactor core chamber and damaged the reactor core itself, which
eventually explodes and destroys the station. It was destroyed by [Wedge
Antilles](/wiki/Wedge_Antilles "Wedge Antilles") and [Lando
Calrissian](/wiki/Lando_Calrissian "Lando Calrissian") (with [Nien
Nunb](/wiki/Nien_Nunb "Nien Nunb") as his _[Millennium
Falcon](/wiki/Millennium_Falcon "Millennium Falcon")_ co-pilot), the former
destroying a power regulator and the latter destroying the main
reactor.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The Death Star II is featured in the cover of the book _[Star Wars:
Aftermath](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Aftermath "Star Wars: Aftermath")_ (2015), which
also features many flashbacks to the destruction of the Death Star II, as well
as the events directly after its destruction. One of the main characters in
the story personally escaped the explosion of the Death Star. The destruction
of the second Death Star was also shown in holograms in the book. The 2015
comic book _[Star Wars: Shattered Empire](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Shattered_Empire
"Star Wars: Shattered Empire")_ also explores the days following the
destruction of the Death Star II from the perspective of [Poe
Dameron](/wiki/Poe_Dameron "Poe Dameron")'s parents, who were pilots during
the event. The video game _[Star Wars: Uprising](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Uprising
"Star Wars: Uprising")_ also takes place during the aftermath of the second
Death Star's destruction, and features a hologram of its description on
multiple occasions in and out of cutscenes.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Similar super weapons of mass
destruction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Similar super weapons of mass destruction")]

#### Malachor Sith Temple - (_Star Wars
Rebels_)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Malachor Sith Temple - \(Star Wars Rebels\)")]

Main article: [Star Wars Rebels](/wiki/Star_Wars_Rebels "Star Wars Rebels")

The _[Star Wars Rebels](/wiki/Star_Wars_Rebels "Star Wars Rebels")_ episode
_Twilight of the Apprentice_ features a forbidden planet called Malachor,[15]
home of an ancient [Sith](/wiki/Sith "Sith") Temple.[16] This temple contained
a Battle Station capable of destroying planets, and could only be activated by
placing a special Sith Holocron[17] in an [obelisk](/wiki/Obelisk "Obelisk")
at the summit of the pyramid inside the temple. Thousands of years prior, a
battle was waged on Malachor that resulted in the deaths of its inhabitants.
Somewhere between the events of his last appearance in [The Clone
Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(2008_TV_series\) "Star Wars: The Clone
Wars \(2008 TV series\)") and this episode, [Darth Maul](/wiki/Darth_Maul
"Darth Maul") had become stranded on Malachor. When [Ahsoka
Tano](/wiki/Ahsoka_Tano "Ahsoka Tano"), Kanan and Ezra arrived, Ezra was
separated from them. He was discovered by a character who later revealed
himself to be Maul. Together, they solved a series of test chambers that
required cooperation between two Force wielders, and retrieved a Sith
Holocron. With the help of Kanan and Ahsoka, they fought three Inquisitors,
all of whom were killed by Maul. Maul then betrayed his allies, blinding
Kanan, and proceeded to activate the Battle Station. Once Maul was defeated by
a sightless Kanan, Darth Vader arrived with the intention of retrieving the
holocron, but was challenged by Ahsoka Tano, his former Padawan. While the
station was preparing to fire, Kanan and Ezra retrieved the holocron
themselves and escaped, preventing this weapon of mass destruction from being
used. Even though the temple was destabilized, Ahsoka and Vader kept fighting
to the death within the rapidly-crumbling building, until it eventually
exploded, wounding Darth Vader and almost killing Ahsoka.[18]

#### Starkiller Base - (_Star Wars: The Force
Awakens_)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Starkiller Base - \(Star Wars: The Force Awakens\)")]

Main article: [Star Wars: The Force
Awakens](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Force_Awakens "Star Wars: The Force Awakens")

_[Star Wars: The Force Awakens](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Force_Awakens "Star Wars:
The Force Awakens")_ features [Starkiller Base](/wiki/Starkiller_Base
"Starkiller Base"), a planet turned into a battle station built by the [First
Order](/wiki/First_Order_\(Star_Wars\) "First Order \(Star Wars\)").
Significantly larger than either the first or second Death Star, and unlike
either of those cost-prohibitive space stations, this battle station cut-costs
by [terraforming](/wiki/Terraforming "Terraforming") an existing planet and
draws its fire power directly from a sun, but it requires time to draw enough
energy. Once fired, it has the power to destroy up to five planets within the
same [star system](/wiki/Star_system "Star system") simultaneously, making it
a far deadlier superweapon than the Death Star. [General
Hux](/wiki/General_Hux "General Hux") gave an intense speech while the
Starkiller Base demonstrated its lethality by obliterating the five planets of
the [Hosnian Prime](/wiki/Hosnian_Prime "Hosnian Prime") system (the location
of the Republic government, which rotates every few years), the cataclysm
witnessed by Han Solo, Chewbacca, Rey and Finn from [Maz
Kanata](/wiki/Maz_Kanata "Maz Kanata")'s castle. After Rey was captured by
[Kylo Ren](/wiki/Kylo_Ren "Kylo Ren"), he interrogated her within the base.
Han, Chewbacca and Finn approached the base at light-speed because the base's
shield kept out anything going under the speed of light. They found Rey and
successfully lowered the protective shields, enabling an X-wing assault led by
[Poe Dameron](/wiki/Poe_Dameron "Poe Dameron") and Nien Numb to destroy the
planet-turned-base, with Poe firing the crucial, destructive shots.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
name Starkiller Base paid homage to the early drafts of the original Star Wars
film, referring to Luke Skywalker's original name as Luke Starkiller.[19][20]

### _Death Star_ s in _Star Wars
Legends_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Death Stars in Star Wars Legends")]

Main article: [Star Wars Legends](/wiki/Star_Wars_Legends "Star Wars Legends")

Both _Death Star_ s appear throughout the non-canonical [_Star Wars_
Legends](/wiki/Expanded_Universe_\(Star_Wars\) "Expanded Universe \(Star
Wars\)") (formerly known as the Expanded Universe).[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The first _Death Star_ 's construction is the subject of [Michael
Reaves](/wiki/Michael_Reaves "Michael Reaves") and [Steve
Perry](/wiki/Steve_Perry_\(author\) "Steve Perry \(author\)")'s novel _[Death
Star](/wiki/Death_Star_\(novel\) "Death Star \(novel\)")_. In
[LucasArts](/wiki/LucasArts "LucasArts")'s _[Star Wars: Battlefront
II](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Battlefront_II_\(2005_video_game\) "Star Wars:
Battlefront II \(2005 video game\)")_ , the player participates in a mission
to secure crystals used in the Death Star's superlaser. The first Death Star
under construction acts as the final stage in the video game, _[The Force
Unleashed](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Force_Unleashed "Star Wars: The Force
Unleashed")_. [Kevin J. Anderson](/wiki/Kevin_J._Anderson "Kevin J.
Anderson")'s _[Jedi Academy](/wiki/Jedi_Academy_trilogy "Jedi Academy
trilogy")_ trilogy introduces the Maw Cluster of [black
holes](/wiki/Black_hole "Black hole") that protect a laboratory where the
_Death Star_ prototype was built (consisting of the super structure, power
core, and superlaser).[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[National Public Radio](/wiki/National_Public_Radio "National Public Radio")'s
[_A New Hope_ adaptation](/wiki/Star_Wars_\(radio\) "Star Wars \(radio\)")
portrays Leia (Ann Sachs) and [Bail Organa](/wiki/Bail_Organa "Bail Organa")'s
([Stephen Elliott](/wiki/Stephen_Elliott_\(actor\) "Stephen Elliott
\(actor\)")) discovery of the Death Star's existence and Leia's mission to
steal the space station's schematics. The first level of LucasArts' _[Dark
Forces](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Dark_Forces "Star Wars: Dark Forces")_ gives the
player a supporting role in Leia's mission, while a mission in _Battlefront
II_ tasks the player with acting as a
[stormtrooper](/wiki/Imperial_stormtrooper "Imperial stormtrooper") or Darth
Vader in an attempt to recover the plans and capture Leia. [Steve
Perry](/wiki/Steve_Perry_\(author\) "Steve Perry \(author\)")'s novel
_[Shadows of the Empire](/wiki/Shadows_of_the_Empire_\(novel\) "Shadows of the
Empire \(novel\)")_ describes a mission that leads to the Rebels learning of
the second Death Star's existence, and that mission is playable in LucasArts'
_[X-Wing Alliance](/wiki/X-Wing_Alliance "X-Wing Alliance")_ [combat flight
simulator](/wiki/Combat_flight_simulator "Combat flight simulator"). Numerous
LucasArts titles recreate the movies' attacks on the Death Stars, and the
Death Star itself is a controllable weapon for the Empire in the
_[Rebellion](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Rebellion_\(video_game\) "Star Wars: Rebellion
\(video game\)")_ and _[Empire at War](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Empire_at_War "Star
Wars: Empire at War")_ strategy game. A Death Star variation appears in [Kevin
J. Anderson](/wiki/Kevin_J._Anderson "Kevin J. Anderson")'s novel
_[Darksaber](/wiki/Darksaber_\(novel\) "Darksaber \(novel\)")_ (1995), and a
prototype version of the Death Star can be found in his novel _[Jedi
Search](/wiki/Jedi_Search "Jedi Search")_ (1994).[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The first Death Star is depicted in various sources of having a crew of
265,675, as well as 52,276 gunners, 607,360 troops, 30,984 stormtroopers,
42,782 ship support staff, and 180,216 pilots and support crew.[21] Its
hangars contain assault shuttles, blastboats, Strike cruisers, land vehicles,
support ships, and 7,293 [TIE fighters](/wiki/TIE_fighter "TIE fighter").[22]
It is also protected by 10,000 turbolaser batteries, 2,600 [ion
cannons](/wiki/Ion_cannon "Ion cannon"), and at least 768 [tractor
beam](/wiki/Tractor_beam "Tractor beam") projectors.[22] Various sources state
the first Death Star has a [diameter](/wiki/Diameter "Diameter") of between
140 and 160 kilometers.[21][23][24] There is a broader range of figures for
the second Death Star's diameter, ranging from 160 to 900 kilometers.[25][26]

#### _DS-X_ Prototype Battle
Station[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: DS-X Prototype Battle Station")]

In the _Legends_ novels _Death Star_ , _Dark Empire II_ , _Jedi Search_ and
_Champions of the Force_ , an experimental _Death Star_ prototype, _**DS-X**_
(a durasteel frame surrounding a reactor core, superlaser, engines and a
control room) was conceived by [Grand Moff Wilhuff
Tarkin](/wiki/Grand_Moff_Tarkin "Grand Moff Tarkin") as a test bed for the
first Death Star. It was constructed by Bevel Lemelisk and his engineers at
the Empire's secret Maw Installation. The prototype measured 120 kilometers in
diameter. Its superlaser was only powerful enough to destroy a planet's core,
rendering it an uninhabitable "dead planet". The targeting system on the
prototype was never calibrated and the superlaser was inefficient, leaving the
weapon's batteries drained. The prototype had no interior except a slave-
linked control room, hyperdrive engines and other components; the station
operated with skeleton-crew of 75 personnel.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

George Lucas himself confirmed that the plans featured in _Attack of the
Clones_ and the under-construction facility in _Revenge of the Sith_ was
indeed the original _Death Star_. The _Star Wars: The New Essential
Chronology_ [retconned](/wiki/Retcon "Retcon") the _DS-X_ prototype into being
built _alongside_ the main _Death Star_.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

#### _Death Star III_ \- (_Star Tours: The Adventures
Continue_)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Death Star III - \(Star Tours: The Adventures Continue\)")]

In the Disney attraction _[Star Tours: The Adventures
Continue](/wiki/Star_Tours:_The_Adventures_Continue "Star Tours: The
Adventures Continue")_ , guests can travel inside an incomplete Death Star
during one of the randomized ride sequences. In the original Star Tours, a
_**Death Star III**_ is seen and destroyed during the ride sequence by the New
Republic. [Leland Chee](/wiki/Leland_Chee "Leland Chee") originally created
the third _Death Star_ to explain why a _Death Star_ is present on the _[Star
Tours](/wiki/Star_Tours "Star Tours")_ ride when both of the stations in the
movies were destroyed.[27] The station being built near the Forest Moon of
Endor like the second _Death Star_ before it is similar to an original concept
for Return of the Jedi, where two _Death Star_ s would have been built near
Had Abbadon (then the Imperial capital world). The _Habitation_ spheres, based
on the Imperials' suspicious claims that they were designed strictly for
peaceful purposes, were suggested by some fans to have been the origin for the
Death Star III. This was later revealed to be the case in Part 2 of the
StarWars.com Blog series _The Imperial Warlords: Despoilers of an Empire_. In
the _[Star Wars Legends](/wiki/Star_Wars_Legends "Star Wars Legends")_ game
_[Tiny Death Star](/wiki/Tiny_Death_Star "Tiny Death Star")_ , a random
HoloNet entry states that one of the residents of the _Death Star_ is simply
staying there until he can afford to stay at the third _Death
Star_.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

## Cultural
influence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Cultural influence")]

The Death Star placed ninth in a 2008 [20th Century
Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox "20th Century Fox") poll of the most popular movie
weapons.[28] It is also referred to outside of the _Star Wars_
context.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[KTCK](/wiki/KTCK_\(AM\) "KTCK \(AM\)") (SportsRadio 1310 The Ticket) in
Dallas were the first to use the term "Death Star" to describe the new mammoth
Cowboys Stadium, now [AT&T Stadium](/wiki/AT%26T_Stadium "AT&T Stadium"), in
[Arlington, Texas](/wiki/Arlington,_Texas "Arlington, Texas"). The term has
since spread to local media and is generally accepted as a proper nickname for
the stadium.[29]

The [Death Star strategy](/wiki/Death_Star_\(business\) "Death Star
\(business\)") was the name [Enron](/wiki/Enron "Enron") gave to one of their
fraudulent business practices for manipulating California's [energy
market](/wiki/Energy_market "Energy market").[30]

[AT&T Corporation](/wiki/AT%26T_Corporation "AT&T Corporation")'s logo
introduced in 1982 is [informally referred to as the "Death
Star"](/wiki/AT%26T_Information_Systems "AT&T Information Systems").[31] _[Ars
Technica](/wiki/Ars_Technica "Ars Technica")_ referred to "the AT&T Death
Star" in an article criticizing a company data policy.[32] Competitor
[T-Mobile](/wiki/T-Mobile "T-Mobile") mocked AT&T's "Death Star" logo and
"Empire-like reputation" in a press release.[33]

### Science[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Science")]

See also: [Physics and Star Wars](/wiki/Physics_and_Star_Wars "Physics and
Star Wars")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Mimas_PIA06258.jpg/170px-
Mimas_PIA06258.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mimas_PIA06258.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mimas_PIA06258.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Saturnian](/wiki/Saturn "Saturn") moon [Mimas](/wiki/Mimas_\(moon\)
"Mimas \(moon\)"), photographed by the
_[Cassini](/wiki/Cassini%E2%80%93Huygens "Cassini–Huygens")_ probe in 2005.
The large crater in the upper right
([Herschel](/wiki/Herschel_\(Mimantean_crater\) "Herschel \(Mimantean
crater\)")) gives it a resemblance to the Death Star.

In 1981, following the _[Voyager](/wiki/Voyager_program "Voyager program")_
spacecraft's flight past [Saturn](/wiki/Saturn "Saturn"), scientists noticed a
resemblance between one of the planet's moons, [Mimas](/wiki/Mimas_\(moon\)
"Mimas \(moon\)"), and the Death Star.[34] Additionally, a few
[astronomers](/wiki/Astronomy
"Astronomy")[_[who?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] sometimes use the term "Death
Star" to describe [Nemesis](/wiki/Nemesis_\(hypothetical_star\) "Nemesis
\(hypothetical star\)"), a hypothetical [star](/wiki/Star "Star") postulated
in 1984 to be responsible for [gravitationally](/wiki/Gravitation
"Gravitation") forcing [comets](/wiki/Comet "Comet") and
[asteroids](/wiki/Asteroid "Asteroid") from the [Oort cloud](/wiki/Oort_cloud
"Oort cloud") toward [Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth").[35]

### Merchandise[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Merchandise")]

[Kenner](/wiki/Kenner_Products "Kenner Products") and
[AMT](/wiki/Aluminum_Metal_Toys "Aluminum Metal Toys") created a playset and a
model, respectively, of the first Death Star.[36][37] In 2005 and 2008,
[Lego](/wiki/Lego "Lego") released models of Death Star II and Death Star I,
respectively.[38][39] In 1979, [Palitoy](/wiki/Palitoy "Palitoy") created a
heavy card version of the Death Star as a playset for the vintage range of
action figures in the UK, Australia and Canada. Both Death Stars are part of
different [Micro Machines](/wiki/Micro_Machines "Micro Machines") three-
packs.[40][41] The Death Stars and locations in them are cards in [Decipher,
Inc.](/wiki/Decipher,_Inc. "Decipher, Inc.")'s and [Wizards of the
Coast](/wiki/Wizards_of_the_Coast "Wizards of the Coast")'s [Star Wars
Customizable Card Game](/wiki/Star_Wars_Customizable_Card_Game "Star Wars
Customizable Card Game") and [Star Wars Trading Card
Game](/wiki/Star_Wars_Trading_Card_Game "Star Wars Trading Card Game"),
respectively.[42] [Hasbro](/wiki/Hasbro "Hasbro") released a Death Star model
that [transforms](/wiki/Transformers_\(toy_line\) "Transformers \(toy line\)")
into a Darth Vader [mech](/wiki/Mecha "Mecha").[43] [Estes
Industries](/wiki/Estes_Industries "Estes Industries") released a flying model
rocket version.[44]

A Death Star trinket box was also released by [Royal
Selangor](/wiki/Royal_Selangor "Royal Selangor") in 2015, in conjunction with
the upcoming December screening of _[Star Wars: The Force
Awakens](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Force_Awakens "Star Wars: The Force
Awakens")_.[45] In 2016, Plox released the official levitating Death Star
Speaker[46] in anticipation of the upcoming screening of _[Rogue One: A Star
Wars Story](/wiki/Rogue_One "Rogue One")_.

### White House
petition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: White House petition")]

In 2012–13, a proposal on the [White House](/wiki/White_House "White House")'s
website urging the United States government to build a real Death Star as an
economic stimulus and job creation measure gained more than 30,000 signatures,
enough to qualify for an official response. The official ([tongue-in-
cheek](/wiki/Tongue-in-cheek "Tongue-in-cheek")) response was released in
January 2013:[47] the cost of building a real Death Star has been estimated at
$850 quadrillion by the [Lehigh University](/wiki/Lehigh_University "Lehigh
University"), or about 13,000 times the amount of mineable resources on
[Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth"), while the _[International Business
Times](/wiki/International_Business_Times "International Business Times")_
cited a Centives economics blog calculation that, at current rates of steel
production, the Death Star would not be ready for more than 833,000 years.[48]
The White House response also stated "the Administration does not support
blowing up planets," and questioned funding a weapon "with a fundamental flaw
that can be exploited by a one-man starship" as reasons for denying the
petition.[47][49][50]

### Petition in other
countries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Death_Star&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Petition in other countries")]

The Luxemburgish magician Christian Lavey (born as Christian Kies) submitted a
petition for the construction of a Death Star to the Luxemburgish parliament
[51]. However, on an interview with a local radio station Lavey admitted that
this petition was just a joke and some kind of protest against the space plans
of the government.
